titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Oversize Ms. Codex 57: Statuti del Bosco

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Oversize Ms. Codex 57: Statuti del Bosco are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. See the Creative Commons Public Domain Mark page for usage details, http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/mark/1.0/.

notesStmt.note: Title from recto of front flyleaf.
Covers and endpapers show a great deal of worm damage. Cover boards warped. Edges of the first and last few folios split and cracked. Folio [i] missing a large section, with some loss of text.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Contains statutes of Bosco Marengo (f. 1-88). Preceding the statutes there is an index, with folio numbers for cross reference (f. [i]-[viii]).

supportDesc.extent: 96 leaves : 275 x 207 (196 x 140) mm. bound to 272 x 210 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Parchment, i (paper) + 96 + i (paper); [viii], 1-88. There are three sets of folio numbers, all of which begin on the ninth leaf (which is numbered f. 1) and which are all written in the upper right corner of each recto: 1.) contemporary roman numerals; 2.) slightly later arabic numerals; 3.) modern pencil arabic numerals, f. 78-end, correcting errors in the first two foliation systems. In the first two foliation systems there are two folios numbered 77, and the numbering in these two systems is incorrect from that point on.

collation.p: I⁴, II-VIII⁵, IX-X⁴, XI¹. There is also one front and one back flyleaf, both paper.

layoutDesc.layout: Written in 34 long lines; ruled in ink.

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Italian notarial bookhand plus a number of later additions in 17th- and 18th-century hands.

binding.p: Scored calf over cardboard, possibly Italian of the 18th century.

origin.p: Written in Italy, ca. 1493 (f. 85r). Folios 87v-end contain 17th-century and 18th-century additions.

history.provenance: Owned by Conte Pietro Civaleri (inside front cover: "P. Civalerius emit die x Aprilis 1843"). Also has stamp of Walter Ashburner, Firenze (f. [viii]v and f. 88v).
